1.Q: What weather phenomenon does hurricane formation mainly depend on?
1.A: Warm water mixing with cold water in the ocean
1.B: Warm and cold fronts mixing in the air
1.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Think about where hurricanes usually get their energy from
1.CorrectFeedback: Warm ocean temperatures provides energy for hurricane formation

2.Q: What is the most dangerous aspect of hurricanes if you live near the coast?
2.B: Getting hit by flying debris from strong winds
2.C: Rapid and unexpected temperature and pressure changes
2.D: The storm surge of the hurricane
2.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: This is what causes the most structural and monetary damage to coastal communities
2.CorrectFeedback: The storm surge threatens coastal areas with severe flooding

3.Q: What is the minimum windspeed needed for a storm to be considered a hurricane?
3.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: What is the minimum windspeed a hurricane must hold
3.CorrectFeedback: Hurricanes are classified as having 74+ mph winds

4.Q: What is the difference between hurricanes, cyclones, and typhoons?
4.A: They are the same weather phenomenon, but called different names based on the ocean basin the storm formed in
4.B: Hurricanes usually form around the equator while cyclones and typhoons form at higher latitudes
4.C: Typhoons have faster windspeeds than cyclones and hurricanes
4.D: Cyclones only have windspeeds of less than 100 mph
4.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: The difference is based only on ocean basins
4.CorrectFeedback: The different terms are used depending on where the storm formed

5.Q: When does a tropical storm become a hurricane?
5.A: When the waves carried by the hurricane reach 2 meters in height
5.C: When its sustained windspeed reaches or exceeds 74 mph
5.D: When the atmospheric pressure of the storm drops below 1000 milibars
5.IncorrectFeedback: What is the deciding factor meteorologists use to classify these storms?
5.CorrectFeedback: The cutoff between hurricane and tropical storm occurs at 74 mph

6.Q: Which quadrant(s) of hurricanes, if any, typically have the fastest windspeeds?
6.A: All quadrants typically have similar windspeeds
6.B: The back right quadrant of the storm
6.C: The back left quadrant of the storm
6.D: The forward right quadrant of the storm
6.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Does forward motion of a storm system add to its windspeed?
6.CorrectFeedback: The entire storm system is moving, adding to windspeeds in the forward right quadrant

7.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep a grown adult off their feet?
7.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
7.CorrectFeedback: An adult human can be carried away by as little as 6 inches of fast-moving water!

8.Q: How deep does moving water have to be to sweep away an average car?
8.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: It does not take much moving water to carry away large objects
8.CorrectFeedback: Average cars start being swept away with around 18 inches of moving water. Trucks and SUVs do not fare much better

9.Q: What is not a danger associated with hurricanes events?
9.B: Damaged power lines and building infrastructure
9.D: Objects being carried by fast winds
9.IncorrectFeedback: This is one of the dangers posed by severe storm events
9.CorrectFeedback: High temperatures are not necessarily associated with hurricanes, unless a fire is started by damaged power lines

10.Q: How much water does a hurricane typically drop on a region?
10.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Not every hurricane floods a region, a few inches of rainfall is already a lot
10.CorrectFeedback: An average hurricane will drop around 6-12 inches of rain over an area

11.Q: What part of a hurricane has the strongest wind and rain?
11.A: The cloud bands around the eye of the hurricane
11.B: The cloud bands at the front edge of the hurricane that hit land first
11.C: The cloud bands at the back edge of the hurricane
11.D: Inside the eye of the hurricane
11.IncorrectFeedback: Consider in which part of a hurricane do you observe the densest cloud bands
11.CorrectFeedback: The clouds around the eye of the storm will carry the fastest winds and heaviest rains

12.Q: How are hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin affected during El nino years?
12.A: The warmer ocean temperatures in the eastern Pacific have no affect on hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean
12.B: There are more hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin
12.C: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin
12.D: There are more hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin but more in the Pacific Basin
12.IncorrectFeedback: Hint: Although ocean temperatures are warmer in the eastern Pacific, wind patterns over the Atlantic are changed during El nino
12.CorrectFeedback: There are less hurricanes in the Atlantic Basin during El nino due to increased vertical wind shear weakening hurricane formation

13.Q: What surface ocean temperature (in Fahrenheit) is required for hurricane development?
13.IncorrectFeedback: A lower surface ocean temperature can help hurricanes form
13.CorrectFeedback: At around 80 degrees Fahrenheit surface ocean temperatures can feed energy to hurricanes

14.Q: How many tropical storms develop over the Atlantic Ocean during a typical hurricane season?
14.IncorrectFeedback: Consider how many tropical storm events you hear about during an average hurricane season
14.CorrectFeedback: Around 10 tropical storms will develop over the Atlantic Ocean, including the Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico

15.Q: What is the diameter of a typical hurricane?
15.CorrectFeedback: Hurricanes are typically around 300 miles wide, but can vary considerably

16.Q: Can hurricanes form directly at the equator?
16.A: Yes, because the ground at the equator is traveling the fastest due to Earth's rotation
16.B: Yes, because the equator has the highest average temperatures
16.C: Yes, because there is a lot of ocean surface area around th equator
16.D: No, because the corioles effect that generates spin in wind patterns is weakest at the equator
16.IncorrectFeedback: Hurricanes do require warm ocean temperatures, however the corioles effect also plays a part its formation
16.CorrectFeedback: The corioles effect is strongest at the poles and weakest at the equator

17.Q: How does vertical wind shear (change in wind speed with height) affect hurricane formation?
17.A: It helps hurricane formation because the change in wind speed generates spin
17.B: It hampers hurricane formation because it disrupts storm structure
17.C: It helps hurricane formation because it distributes warm air around the storm
17.D: It generally has no effect on hurricane development
17.IncorrectFeedback: Wind shear does affect hurricane development, and dispersing warm air does not benefit the storm
17.CorrectFeedback: The change in wind speed destroys the storms structure and disperses air parcels above the storm

18.Q: What combination of factors gives the best chance for hurricane development?
18.A: High humidity, low vertical wind shear, warm ocean surface temperature
18.B: High humidity, high vertical wind shear, warm air temperatures
18.C: Low humidity, high rate of evaporation
18.D: Low humidity, low vertical wind shear, cold ocean surface temperatures
18.CorrectFeedback: These factors all benefit hurricane development. Watch out for these conditions on weather forecasts!

19.Q: How far out from the center of a large hurricane can hurricane-force winds extend?
19.IncorrectFeedback: Try again. Fast winds can extend far out from the hurricanes center
19.CorrectFeedback: You might experience hurricane force winds 150 or more miles out from the hurricanes center

20.Q: What is the most active month of hurricane season historically?
20.IncorrectFeedback: Try again. Hurricane season lasts from early June to late November
20.CorrectFeedback: September is the most active month historically
